summary: In topic 3.1, we learned that enzymes can both break apart and join substrates. However, as with most things, it's much harder to build than destroy. Topic 3.3 explains the energy cells need to join molecules.

vocab.definition: All the chemical reactions that occur within a living organism to maintain life, growth, and repair
The fundamental capacity to do work, existing as either potential energy (stored, like chemical) or kinetic energy (in motion, like heat)
Chemical reactions that create bonds to store energy within molecules; decreases free energy
Chemical reactions that break unstable bonds in molecules to release energy; decreases stored energy
A molecule found in all living cells that serves as the primary energy carrier, releasing energy when its bonds are broken
A molecule that is converted from ATP when energy is released for cellular work, with the loss of a phosphate group
The process where an exergonic reaction (one that releases energy) drives an endergonic reaction (one that requires energy)
Energy cannot be created or destroyed, only transformed from one form to another within an isolated system
The entropy of an isolated system tends to increase, meaning biological processes naturally move towards states of greater disorder and energy dispersal
A measure of the randomness or disorder within a biological system and the dispersal of energy
The portion of a system's energy that is available to do useful work, such as driving metabolic processes
